thread.title: 17 Ways To Make A Small Room Feel So Big
thread.title_full: 17 Ways To Make A Small Room Feel So Big

author: Julie Gerstein
title: 17 Ways To Make A Small Room Feel So Big

organizations.name: darren palmer interiors lourdes gabriela interiors

text:
View this image ›
Charlotte Gomez/BuzzFeed ID: 10364919 1. Skip the coffee table and use cute ottomans instead. They’ll double as extra seating when you need ‘em. View this image ›
Tobi Fairley Interior Design / Via houzz.com ID: 10349857 2. Rather than buying a bulky night table, use a step stool instead. View this image ›
Tiffany Grant-Riley / Via houzz.com A repurposed step stool will definitely save you money and space.
ID: 10350040 3. Use neutral colors and similar colors to create an optical illusion of spaciousness. View this image ›
Amy Lau Design / Via houzz.com Neutral-toned fabrics add light and space to small rooms and continuing the same color on the floor helps to add to the idea of space.
ID: 10349914 4. Horizontal stripes can help make a room feel wider. View this image ›
Joseph Eastburn Photography/Sarah Phipps Design / Via houzz.com Use blankets and rugs you already have lying around.
ID: 10349981 5. Skip a headboard — use a bookcase that’ll double as a headboard instead. View this image ›
Peter Landers Photography / Via houzz.com ID: 10349866 6. Why only hang one row of hooks when you could hang two? View this image ›
Kayne Designs / Via houzz.com Even better if your hooks are cute and design-y.
ID: 10350277 7. Save floor space by hanging lighting from the ceiling! View this image ›
Emily Andrews You can find pendant lamps at Ikea starting at around $25.
ID: 10349884 8. If you don’t have much room, go for a round table over a square one. They can easily fit into corners if you need ‘em to. View this image ›
Megan Blake Design / Via houzz.com Extra bonus: No sharp corners to run into!
ID: 10350072 9. Sometimes you can find unexpected spaces — like a closet, or a landing — to put a desk or work area. Applegate Tran Interiors
CWB Architects/ houzz.com
 If you’re short on square footage, think creatively about how to use the space you’ve got. What are some typically undervalued home areas — like hallways, landings, and closets — that could be repurposed into active spaces?
ID: 10353414 10. OMG YOU GUYS, THESE DIAGONAL DRAWERS! View this image ›
Glenvale Kitchens / Via houzz.com If you can afford custom drawers like these … well, just imagine. What. a. game-changer.
ID: 10350136 11. Employ mirrors to give the illusion of more space. Darren Palmer Interiors
Lourdes Gabriela Interiors/ houzz.com
 For optimal ~space~, place your mirror on a wall adjacent, not opposite, your windows.
ID: 10353684 12. And if you can swing it, use a full-height mirror to really add space to a room and give the illusion of higher ceilings. View this image ›
Brown + Brown Architects / Via houzz.com ID: 10354610 13. If you can’t build out, build up! Hamilton Snowber Architects
Lark Architecture/ houzz.com
 Think about ways you can use the vertical space if no horizontal square footage is available.
ID: 10350275 14. Hang curtains directly from the ceiling to give the illusion of more height. View this image ›
Stern McCafferty / Via houzz.com ID: 10354585 15. Fake more space by employing clear glass, acrylic, or plastic furniture. View this image ›
Seth Caplan / sheep + stone / Via houzz.com That coffee table is practically invisible, lol.
ID: 10349899 16. Use furniture pieces that’ll do double duty. View this image ›
Mia Karlsson Interior Design / Via houzz.com For example, this credenza serves as a convenient bedside table, and also a great dresser and storage unit.
ID: 10350005 17. And no matter the size of your room, adding plants will give your space a sense of lushness and depth. View this image ›
Jamie Laubhan-Oliver / Via houzz.com Plus they’re rea purrrrty.
